paragraphs:
[1]
Harrington, J.
: This is an appeal by Mr. Deldelian of a decision of a Citizenship Judge who denied his application for citizenship on the grounds that he did not meet the residency requirement. Section 5(1)(c) of the
Citizenship Act
in force at the relevant time required a permanent resident to have accumulated at least three years of residence in Canada within the four years immediately preceding the date of the application, which in this case was 7 March 2010. Mr. Deldelian certainly cut it close. He claimed he was physically present in Canada for 1,096 days during that four-year period, i.e. three years plus one day.

[2]
Citizenship judges, and this Court, have wrestled for many years with the meaning of "residence" within the
Citizenship Act
. Some judges have used a physical presence test while others have taken a more nuanced approach. In
Re Papadogiorgakis
, [1978] 2 FC 208 (TD), Associate Chief Justice Thurlow, as he then was, held that if a person was established here he did not cease to be a resident when he leaves for a temporary purpose. In
Re Koo
, [1993] 1 FC 286, Madam Justice Reed said the test was whether Canada was the place where the applicant "regularly, normally or customarily lives". However, in
Re Pourghasemi,
(1993), 62 FTR 122, Mr. Justice Muldoon applied a strict physical presence test.

[3]
Our jurisprudence developed such that an appeal would not be granted if the Citizenship Judge selected and reasonably applied any one of these tests. Fortunately, Parliament has finally resolved this dilemma with the passage of the
Strengthening of the Canadian Citizenship Act,
SC 2014, c 22. The test is now physical presence of 1,460 days over the six-year period preceding the application, with at least 183 days of physical presence in each of the four last calendar years.

[4]
In this case, the Citizenship Judge applied the strict physical presence test and was not persuaded that Mr. Deldelian was here the required number of days. Without doubt, the burden fell upon him (
 <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> ).

[5]
It cannot be said that the record clearly shows that Mr. Deldelian was absent for at least 2 days of the 1,096 days he claimed to be present here. The Citizenship Judge simply did not believe him, and set out several reasons why. Counsel for Mr. Deldelian submits that some of the judge's statements are clearly wrong, that she failed to focus on the four years which were in issue, and that some of her doubts were perverse and capricious.

[6]
He has persuaded me that that is indeed the case. The appeal shall be granted and the matter referred back to another Citizenship Judge.
I.
The decision under appeal

[7]
The judge formed the view that Mr. Deldelian was a scofflaw. Consequently, she did not give him any benefit of the doubt whatsoever.

[8]
The first issue relates to Employment Insurance. After he was declared redundant from his job in Montréal, Mr. Deldelian applied for EI benefits. He was approved on 28 July 2009 which benefits expired in mid-September that year. In the citizenship forms he was required to fill in, he declared that he was absent from the country four times during this overall timeframe. The first two absences were before he was approved. The third absence, which was to meet a prospective employer, not to actually work, was on the day he was approved. The fourth absence occurred after his benefits had expired in mid-September 2009.

[9]
The Citizenship Judge concluded that one could not leave the country and also claim EI benefits. She was also most concerned with the fact that Mr. Deldelian did not provide a satisfactory explanation as to why he departed from Canada the very day he submitted his citizenship application. This concern was irrelevant, as the four years in question ended the day before. Had the Citizenship Judge been dealing with the Act, as amended by the
Strengthening of the Canadian
Citizenship Act
, this would have been a relevant consideration as one of the requirements is that the applicant intends to continue to reside in Canada.

[10]
Another issue raised is that there were two entries in the government datasheets that had not been listed by Mr. Deldelian in his application. These entries combined with stamps in his passport evidence two day trips. The forms he was required to fill in are somewhat confusing in that although he was called upon to list all trips out of the country, day trips do not count for the purpose of calculating the number of days one is out of the country.

[11]
Further, although there were various bank transactions which Mr. Deldelian claimed evidenced that he was in Canada, the Citizenship Judge would not accept these bank records as evidence because the account was operated jointly by Mr. Deldelian and his wife, and did not establish that he was in Canada. On the other hand, they did not establish that he was outside the country.

[12]
One troubling point relates to his LinkedIn profile which showed him as the General Manager of a hotel in Doha, Qatar, from 2009 to 2011. Although the Citizenship Judge accepted that the entry was incorrect as it was in obvious contradiction to his other claim that he was a hotel consultant in Montréal from October 2009 to March 2010, she did not accept his explanation as to why the entry was incorrect. His explanation was that he had made the entry in the expectation that he would obtain a job in Qatar. However, as a Jordanian, he encountered difficulties in obtaining a work permit. The LinkedIn entry is also somewhat suspect because there are medical records showing that he was in Montréal at least part of that time.

[13]
If the Citizenship Judge had limited her analysis to the four years immediately preceding Mr. Deldelian's application, it would have been necessary for me to determine whether her decision was sufficiently reasonable to withstand review in accordance with
 <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> , particularly at paragraph 47. However, in addition to raising an issue with respect to his departure from Canada on the day he filed his application, she dealt with his son's schooling the year following, and the exact role of his wife in his business following his citizenship application. It is not at all clear that the Citizenship Judge limited herself to the four years in issue. Indeed, she considered events which took place after he applied for citizenship. As stated by Mr. Justice O'Keefe in
 <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> : [39] From a perusal of the reasons, it cannot be determined whether the citizenship judge was referring to the extensive absences from Canada after February 14, 2003, the date of the applicant's application, or just the absences prior to the date of his application. I cannot tell whether the citizenship judge took into account the absences after the date of the application in arriving at a conclusion on the applicant's application. If she did, it would constitute a reviewable error. [40] Accordingly, the appeal of the citizenship judge's decision must be allowed, as there is a live issue as to the actual number of days the applicant was absent from Canada. I will refer the matter back to a different citizenship judge for redetermination.
See also
 <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> .

[14]
The appeal shall be granted.
JUDGMENT

[15]
THIS COURT'S JUDGMENT is that
:
1. The appeal from a decision of the Citizenship Judge, dated 27 August 2013, is granted.
2. The application is referred back to another Citizenship Judge for redetermination.
Appeal allowed.

statutes: Strengthening of the Canadian Citizenship Act, SC 2014, c 22
legal_issues: The proper interpretation and application of statutory residency requirements for naturalization.
The standard of review applicable to decisions of administrative tribunals regarding factual findings.
The admissibility of evidence to establish physical presence for residency purposes.
The relevance of post-application conduct to a determination of prior residency.
The scope of permissible inquiry for an administrative decision-maker when assessing eligibility criteria.
Whether an administrative decision-maker's disbelief of an applicant's testimony is justified and reasonable.
The impact of conflicting evidence on the determination of residency status.
factual_background: An individual applied for Canadian citizenship on March 7, 2010.

The application was denied by a Citizenship Judge due to insufficient residency, specifically not meeting the requirement of at least three years of physical presence in Canada within the four years prior to the application date.
The applicant claimed 1,096 days of physical presence in Canada during the relevant four-year period.

The applicant received Employment Insurance (EI) benefits after being declared redundant from a job in Montréal, and had four reported absences from the country during the period of EI eligibility and shortly thereafter.
The Citizenship Judge questioned the applicant's departure from Canada on the day of the citizenship application.
Two unreported day trips were identified through government datasheets and passport stamps.
Bank records submitted as proof of presence were discounted because the account was jointly held with the applicant's wife.

A LinkedIn profile indicated the applicant was employed as a hotel manager in Doha, Qatar from 2009 to 2011, which the applicant explained as an incorrect entry made in anticipation of a job that did not materialize due to work permit issues.
Medical records indicated the applicant was in Montréal during at least part of the time he was purportedly employed in Qatar.
The Citizenship Judge considered events occurring after the date of the citizenship application, specifically regarding the applicant's son's schooling and his wife's business role.

Applicants: Claimed physical presence in Canada for 1,096 days within the relevant four-year period, meeting the residency requirement.
Argued the Citizenship Judge's statements were incorrect and focused on irrelevant timeframes beyond the four-year period in question.
Contended the judge's doubts were perverse and capricious.
Explained the Employment Insurance (EI) benefits were received legitimately, as absences occurred before approval or after benefits expired.
Asserted the departure on the day of application was irrelevant as it fell outside the four-year calculation period.
Stated the two unreported day trips were not relevant as day trips do not count against residency.
Maintained bank records, though joint, did not prove absence from Canada.

Explained the incorrect LinkedIn profile entry as a result of a job application expectation that did not materialize due to work permit issues, supported by medical records showing presence in Montreal.
Argued the Citizenship Judge improperly considered events *after* the application date.
Respondents: Applied a strict physical presence test and found Mr. Deldelian did not meet the required number of days.
Disbelieved Mr. Deldelian's claim of 1,096 days of physical presence.
Found it problematic that Mr. Deldelian claimed EI benefits while also being outside of Canada.
Raised concerns about Mr. Deldelian's departure from Canada on the day of his citizenship application.
Highlighted two unreported day trips evidenced by government datasheets and passport stamps.
Disregarded joint bank account records as insufficient proof of presence in Canada.
Questioned Mr. Deldelian's explanation for the incorrect LinkedIn profile entry, despite accepting it contradicted other claims.
Considered events occurring after the application date in assessing residency.

court_analysis: The court allowed Mr. Deldelian’s appeal of the Citizenship Judge’s decision denying his citizenship application, finding the judge’s reasoning flawed and potentially exceeding the scope of permissible consideration.

The court acknowledged the historical ambiguity in interpreting “residence” under the Citizenship Act, noting the varying approaches taken by previous judges (physical presence vs. a more nuanced ‘regular life’ test) but emphasized that this ambiguity was resolved by the 2014 amendments to the Act.

The Citizenship Judge applied a strict physical presence test, but the court found the judge’s application of this test was tainted by a pre-conceived negative view of the applicant as a 'scofflaw', leading to a lack of impartiality and a refusal to grant any benefit of the doubt.

The court found the judge erred in considering factors irrelevant to the four-year residency period, specifically Mr. Deldelian’s departure on the day *after* the relevant period ended and post-application events like his son’s schooling and his wife’s business role.

The court determined the judge improperly discounted evidence (bank records) without a clear rationale and failed to adequately address Mr. Deldelian’s explanation regarding a misleading entry on his LinkedIn profile, despite contradictory evidence (medical records).

The court relied on precedent (O’Keefe J. in a previous case) establishing that if a Citizenship Judge considers absences *after* the application date, it constitutes a reviewable error because the assessment should be limited to the four-year period preceding the application.

Because the court could not determine whether the judge’s decision was based solely on evidence within the relevant four-year period, and due to the demonstrated bias, the court ordered the matter referred back to a different Citizenship Judge for a fresh determination.
final_outcome: The appeal from a decision of the Citizenship Judge, dated 27 August 2013, is granted.
The application is referred back to another Citizenship Judge for redetermination.
